preposition.description: At a higher level or layer than.
examples: watching a television hanging over the bar

preposition.description: Higher than or more than (a specified number or quantity)
examples: they have lived together for over a year
inventories have been refined over many years

preposition.description: By means of; by the medium of.
examples: a voice came over the loudspeaker

adverb.description: Expressing passage or trajectory across an area.
examples: he leaned over and tapped me on the hand

adverb.description: Beyond and falling or hanging from a point.
examples: listing over at an acute angle

adverb.description: Used to express action and result.
Used to express repetition of a process.
examples: the sums will have to be done over again

noun.description: A sequence of six balls bowled by a bowler from one end of the pitch.

phrases: We seem to be over the stomach problems now.
Wendy has been advised to stay on HRT for only five years, when she should be over her symptoms.
If I can keep it up right through the weekend I reckon I'll be over the worst of it.
Please just strike me down here and now because I am just destined to never be over any of this.
origin: Old English ofer, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch over and German über, from an Indo-European word (originally a comparative of the element represented by -ove in above) which is also the base of Latin super and Greek huper.
